Authors: Yu, L.; Wang, L.; Cai, J.; Yang, Z.; Bashir, A.K.; Wen, L.; Wang, W.
Title: Consumer Electronics and GenAI Providing User Experiences in Mental Health
Affiliations: Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiiang, China; Manchester Metropolitan University, Manchester, Greater Manchester, United Kingdom; Chitkara University, Pradesh, HP, India; Macau University of Science and Technology, Taipa, Macao; Shenzhen MSU-BIT University, Shenzhen, Guangdong, China
Authors with affiliations: Yu, Le, Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiiang, China; Wang, Lina, Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiiang, China; Cai, Jijing, Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiiang, China; Yang, Zijia, Zhejiang Agriculture and Forestry University, Hangzhou, Zhejiiang, China; Bashir, Ali Kashif, Manchester Metropolitan University, Manchester, Greater Manchester, United Kingdom, Chitkara University, Pradesh, HP, India; Wen, Long, Macau University of Science and Technology, Taipa, Macao; Wang, Wei, Shenzhen MSU-BIT University, Shenzhen, Guangdong, China
Abstract: As consumer electronics become more ubiquitous and generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) technologies advance rapidly, processing and analyzing semantic information collected from users to enhance their experiences becomes especially important. Traditionally, monitoring students’ educational and psychological health has relied primarily on teachers, a method that is both inefficient and inadequate for comprehensively grasping students’ needs. Therefore, the application of artificial intelligence is particularly critical. GenAI has the capability to gather semantic information from consumer electronics commonly used by students, such as smartphones, wearable devices, and tablets, and perform in-depth analysis. By analyzing curriculum schedules, GenAI can personalize learning paths and predict students’ psychological states through examining individual mental health and media usage data. This article explores how GenAI processes this information to intervene in students’ education and psychological health, and discusses the analysis of adolescent mental health test data collected in recent years as well. Evidence suggests that students enrolled in high schools suffer from the highest rates of depression and major depressive disorder compared to other stages, at 40% and 12.5%, respectively, underscoring the importance of using GenAI for educational and psychological health monitoring. The article summarizes the relevant technologies and models, highlighting the potential of GenAI in enhancing student well-being and academic performance. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Weiss, B.P.; Rosenthal, R.J.
Author full names: Weiss, Brett P. (60124881000); Rosenthal, Raúl Jacobo (35592115900)
Title: Artificial Intelligence in Laparoscopic Surgery
Affiliations: University of Miami Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine, Miami, FL, United States; Division of General Surgery, Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weiss, Brett P., University of Miami Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine, Miami, FL, United States; Rosenthal, Raúl Jacobo, Division of General Surgery, Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into laparoscopic surgery is transforming surgical practice by enhancing preoperative planning, intraoperative guidance, and postoperative monitoring. AI-driven technologies, including deep learning for lesion detection, 3D anatomical modeling, and augmented reality visualization, are improving surgical precision and reducing complications. AI-based preoperative planning assists in lesion identification and anatomical segmentation, while intraoperative applications leverage machine learning for tissue tracking, surgical navigation, and computer vision. Postoperatively, AI supports real-time monitoring via wearable devices and predictive analytics for complications such as sepsis and ileus. Additionally, AI is advancing surgical education by providing automated skill assessments and real-time feedback in training simulations. The expanding role of AI in surgery presents significant opportunities for improving patient outcomes but also raises ethical concerns regarding bias, data security, and accountability. This chapter reviews the latest research on AI applications in laparoscopic surgery, emphasizing its clinical impact, limitations, and future directions. © 2025 The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Title: Quantifying motor–cognitive reserve using a novel multi-modal stress test
Affiliations: Laboratory of Early Markers of Neurodegeneration, Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel; Department of Statistics and Operations Research, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel; Gray Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel; Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel; Cognition, Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel; Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Rush Alzheimer’s Disease Center, Chicago, IL, United States; Department of Physical Therapy, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel; Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel

Abstract: Reserve is a physiological capacity used under demanding situations. The concept was developed to account for the discrepancy between pathology and clinical manifestation. In neuroscience, motor, brain and cognitive reserves are abstract measures, conceptually defined yet elusive to quantify. Reserve is indirectly assessed using proxies such as years of education and brain volume, limiting its utility. Moreover, the dichotomy in definitions of cognitive and motor reserves is artificial, as daily function requires an intricate network of connections between these domains. Here, we assessed the validity of a newly developed graded motor cognitive ‘stress test’ to quantify the combined motor and cognitive reserve (MCR). The study included 144 participants (ages between 18 and 85, 50% women) with a range of reserve capacities (i.e. healthy young and older adults and individuals with Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, dementia with Lewy bodies and mild cognitive impairment). The assessment included walking on a treadmill while negotiating motor and cognitive challenges delivered using virtual reality. To establish an MCR index score, we used a semi-supervised machine learning algorithm. The model includes performance measures from completing the stress test and measures obtained from wearable sensors used during the test. Validation of the proposed MCR index was examined through: (i) model face validity–reflecting decline of performance as challenge increased; (ii) known-groups validity—classification of scores according to neurological status; (iii) construct validity (convergent)—association with common MCRs proxies as well as MRI-derived regional brain volumes. The model’s face validity revealed decreased performance with increased motor and cognitive challenges (both domains P < 0.001). The index accurately discriminated between healthy controls and those diagnosed with neurological conditions with an area under the curve of 0.89 [95% CI: 0.79–0.99] which was significantly higher than all other commonly used proxies. Statistically significant Spearman’s ρ correlations were observed with all commonly used motor and cognitive proxies (0.56 ≤ r ≤ 0.79, after multiplicity correction all P < 0.05), reflecting construct validity. In addition, statistically significant correlations were observed between the MCR index and whole-brain grey matter and white matter volumes (r = 0.63 and 0.55), as well as the pre-defined left and right caudate nucleus (r = 0.56 and 0.68) and inferior-frontal gyrus (r = 0.47 and 0.58). This proof-of-concept study shows that the novel MCR index is valid, with high sensitivity to neurological deficits and is able to quantify reserve on an individual level. This new innovative tool can assist in screening for motor cognitive deficits and potentially, for predicting motor and cognitive decline associated with neurodegenerative disease. © The Author(s) 2025. Authors: Zhou, W.; Hu, X.; Wei, W.
Title: Multimodal Learning Analytics Using Wearable Devices in Immersive Virtual Reality Learning Environments: A Systematic Review on Learning Indicators and Ethical Considerations
Affiliations: Faculty of Applied Sciences, Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Faculty of Education, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, Wenxiang, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Hu, Xiao, Faculty of Education, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Wei, Wei, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao
Abstract: This systematic literature review explores the application of multimodal learning analysis (MMLA), with physiological signals collected through wearable devices as the primary data source, in immersive virtual reality (IVR) learning environments. By examining 78 peer-reviewed articles published over the past nine years (2016-2024), the paper addresses two core research questions in IVR learning environments: 1) What are the main multimodal learning indicators? 2) What are the ethical considerations associated with multimodal learning analysis? The findings indicate that cognitive indicators are dominant, while studies on emotional and affective learning indicators remain scarce. Real-time monitoring of cognitive load and dynamic task adjustment mechanisms have yet to be fully implemented, suggesting future research on the design of adaptive learning tasks. Additionally, the review calls for improvements in both technological and ethical frameworks to address issues related to privacy, transparency, and fairness. By reviewing and summarizing current research advancements, this paper offers valuable insights into future research and practice of MMLA in IVR learning environments. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Kumar, R.; Singh, A.; Singh, V.
Author full names: Kumar, Ravinder (59370641400); Singh, Avishek (60021861400); Singh, Vikram (59371524400)
Title: Evidence-Based Interventions and Functional Outcomes for Return to Sport After ACL Reconstruction: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
Affiliations: Department of Physical Education, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Ravinder, Department of Physical Education, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India; Singh, Avishek, Department of Physical Education, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India; Singh, Vikram, Department of Physical Education, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, UP, India
Abstract: Background: Rehabilitation is pivotal in supporting return-to-sport (RTS) outcomes following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR); however, inconsistencies in intervention protocols, assessment metrics, and psychological support challenge clinical decision-making. Objective: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated the clinical effectiveness of multidisciplinary rehabilitation strategies—including strength training, neuromuscular re-education, psychological readiness, blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy, and wearable sensor technologies—on functional recovery and RTS outcomes post-ACLR. Methods: Based on bibliometric trends showing substantial growth in ACLR research, a comprehensive literature search of Scopus, PubMed, Web of Science, and IEEE Xplore databases from 2018 to 2024 was conducted. A total of 73 studies were included. Pooled standardized mean differences (SMDs) were computed using random-effects meta-analyses. Methodological quality and evidence strength were assessed via AMSTAR-2 and GRADE tools. Results: Strength and neuromuscular training significantly enhanced quadriceps recovery and limb symmetry (SMD = 0.64; p < 0.01), while BFR therapy showed large effects on hypertrophy and early function (SMD = 1.28; p < 0.0001). Psychological readiness (e.g., ACL-RSI, IKDC) strongly predicted RTS (SMD = 0.82; p < 0.0001). Wearable sensors and machine learning models improved gait tracking and RTS prediction (SMD = 0.46; p < 0.0001), though protocol variability persisted. Conclusion: Multimodal rehabilitation integrating physical, psychological, and technological domains optimizes RTS outcomes post-ACLR. Standardizing intervention criteria and validating sensor-based and AI-supported tools are essential next steps for evidence-based clinical translation. Authors: Weingarden, H.; Holstein, V.; Jonathan, G.K.; Armey, M.; Onnela, J.-P.; Wilhelm, S.
Author full names: Weingarden, Hilary M. (36984554200); Holstein, Vincent L. (57219589067); Jonathan, Geneva Kay (57189659738); Armey, Michael A. (8251028100); Onnela, Jukka Pekka J. (6602641822); Wilhelm, Sabine (7102310648)
Title: Low-Burden Detection of Clinical Worsening in Body Dysmorphic Disorder Using Smartphone Sensor and Demographic Data
Affiliations: Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, United States; Butler Hospital, Providence, RI, United States; Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weingarden, Hilary M., Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, United States; Holstein, Vincent L., Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, United States; Jonathan, Geneva Kay, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, United States; Armey, Michael A., Butler Hospital, Providence, RI, United States; Onnela, Jukka Pekka J., Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, United States; Wilhelm, Sabine, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, United States
Abstract: Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) is characterized by distressing preoccupations with perceived appearance flaws, leading to functional impairment and suicidal ideation (SI). Traditional approaches for monitoring clinical deterioration in BDD include self-reports and clinician assessments, which can miss acute changes in risk due to infrequent administration and recall biases. Alternatively, real-time monitoring via smartphones and wearable devices can enable low-burden early detection of deterioration, identifying intervention opportunities before someone’s condition critically worsens. This study tests the feasibility of using smartphone sensor and demographic data to predict daily clinical acuity. Eighty-two participants with BDD completed ecological momentary assessments (EMA) over 28 days, reporting levels of SI, BDD-related avoidance, and time spent on BDD-related concerns. Smartphone sensor data were collected for 3 months that overlapped with EMA. Machine learning models were trained to predict same-day levels of SI, avoidance, and time spent on BDD using the Global Positioning System (GPS), accelerometer, and demographic data. We evaluated model performance using mean absolute error, Pearson and Spearman correlations, and permutation tests. Random forest(RF) models using time and random split validation outperformed dummy regressor models across outcomes (maximum SI, mean SI, maximum avoidance, mean avoidance, time spent on BDD-related behaviors). Pearson correlations for RF models showed strong predictive performance for BDD-related time (r = .74–.75) and mean and max SI (r = .70–.73). Mean and max avoidance was moderately well predicted (r = .56–.62). Step count and demographic factors (e.g., education, living situation) were the most consistent and important features. This study provides initial evidence that smartphone sensor and demographic data can be used to monitor real-time clinical worsening in BDD, without burdening the patient. This work has potential for building just-in-time interventions that are delivered as deterioration onsets, to prevent its escalation. Future research should test these models in real-world datasets collected over longer periods and subsequently explore integration into interventions and clinical decision making. Title: The Future of Education: How IoT Enhances Teaching and Learning
Affiliations: Poornima Institute of Engineering & Technology, Jaipur, RJ, India

Abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is remodeling the schooling landscape by using connecting devices and growing interactive, statistics-pushed getting to know environments. This paper examines how IoT complements every coaching and studying through upgrades like smart school rooms, actual-time remarks, and custom designed schooling. IoT-enabled gear including sensors, smartboards, and wearable facilitate extra attractive and responsive mastering memories. This generation allow educators to display pupil participation, track overall performance, and tailor coaching to meet person desires, improving instructional outcomes. Moreover, IoT optimizes beneficial useful resource manage in schools, automating systems like lighting fixtures, temperature control, and gadget utilization. Despite its ability, the implementation of IoT in training faces annoying conditions. Data privacy worries, high infrastructure prices, and the hazard of widening the digital divide present barriers to considerable adoption. Overcoming these problems is essential to make sure equitable get proper of entry to and steady use of IoT in school rooms. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd. 2025.

Authors: Kulanthaivel Lakshmanan, L.K.; Kavisankar, K.; Balasubramani, B.
Author full names: Kulanthaivel Lakshmanan, Logesh Kumar (60152154500); Kavisankar, L. (39361573900); Balasubramani, S. (57140557600)
Title: Stress Detection Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning Techniques: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
Source title: Archives of Computational Methods in Engineering
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, TN, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, K L Deemed to be University, Vaddeswaram, AP, India
Authors with affiliations: Kulanthaivel Lakshmanan, Logesh Kumar, Faculty of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, TN, India; Kavisankar, L., Faculty of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, TN, India; Balasubramani, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, K L Deemed to be University, Vaddeswaram, AP, India
Abstract: Stress has emerged as a major issue in today’s world, impacting people in numerous areas of their lives. It originates from multiple sources and can be classified into different types and categories. Physiological stress, exerts high pressure on the human body, disrupting daily activities and overall well-being. Prolonged exposure to elevated stress levels may lead to severe health complications, including cardiovascular diseases and other stress-induced disorders. To mitigate these risks, it is crucial to continuously monitor stress levels, enabling early detection and timely intervention. This systematic review explores various stress detection methodologies, including data-driven approaches that leverage online social networks (OSNs) and physiological signals, such as Electroencephalography (EEG) and Electrocardiography (ECG). Additionally, it explores stress indicators derived from wearable devices, including Galvanic Skin Response (GSR), and Skin Temperature (ST). The study further investigates the application of Machine Learning (ML) techniques and Deep Learning (DL) techniques in examining these signals to improve the accuracy of stress detection. Furthermore, this paper examines the utilization of stress detection models across multiple sectors, including the workplace, education, and the automotive industry. It also highlights key research aspects such as objectives, data sources, data analysis, ML or DL methodologies, and model performance evaluation. The review follows the PICO framework (Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome) to systematically identify relevant studies, define inclusion criteria, and evaluate the impact of computational models on stress detection outcomes. To provide a quantitative summary of performance across studies, this systematic review incorporates meta-analysis using forest plots and funnel plots. By reviewing existing methodologies, this review aims to identify research gaps and outline potential future directions in the field of stress monitoring, thereby supporting the development of more effective and dependable stress management solutions. © The Author(s) under exclusive licence to International Center for Numerical Methods in Engineering (CIMNE) 2025.

Authors: Hijry, H.; Olawoyin, R.
Author full names: Hijry, Hassan M. (57194160697); Olawoyin, Richard (55340142000)
Title: HUMAN-CENTERED STRESS MONITORING IN SMART ASSEMBLY LINES USING EXPLAINABLE AI WITH SHAP
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Tabuk, Tabuk, Tabuk, Saudi Arabia; School of Engineering and Computer Science, Rochester, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hijry, Hassan M., Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Tabuk, Tabuk, Tabuk, Saudi Arabia; Olawoyin, Richard, School of Engineering and Computer Science, Rochester, MI, United States
Abstract: In manufacturing process automation and systems optimization, worker health and well-being face increasing challenges, with stress monitoring becoming crucial, particularly on assembly lines. This study presents a novel stress-monitoring framework designed for high-pressure manufacturing environments, seamlessly integrating IoT, AI, and advanced data analytics. Leveraging data from IoT-enabled wearable devices, we developed a robust machine learning model. A rigorous methodology guided the development and evaluation of four classifiers: Random Forest (RF), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Decision Trees (DT), and XGBoost, with RF proving most effective for our dataset. We initially selected 35 candidate models, establishing a baseline with an RF model due to its strength in handling data complexity. To assess generalizability, another candidate model was randomly chosen to simulate unseen data. A key component was the use of SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) for feature engineering, enhancing model transparency by offering insights into feature importance and decision-making. Additionally, SMOTE addressed class imbalance, while Optuna fine-tuned hyperparameters for improved generalization. The best model achieved 97.40% accuracy (Random Forest) in distinguishing between stressed and non-stressed states. This study applied the advanced method toward Industry 4.0 alongside advancements in smart manufacturing, emphasizing the importance of worker productivity and well-being. As a result, this application of machine learning empowers manufacturers to enhance operational efficiency, reduce costs, and maintain a high standard of product quality. © © 2025 by ASME.

Authors: Hao, M.
Title: Evaluation of Physical Education Teaching Quality in Colleges Based on Hybrid Genetic Algorithm-Optimized Neural Network
Affiliations: Wuhan Donghu University, Wuhan, Hubei, China
Authors with affiliations: Hao, Min, Wuhan Donghu University, Wuhan, Hubei, China
Abstract: The quality of physical education (PE) instruction in colleges has great effects on student health and the development of skills. In traditional ways, however, evaluation can be inefficient and subjective, which results in uneven judgments. Here, this research suggests a neural network-based method to assess PE instruction quality in order to overcome the shortcomings of traditional methods. The study considers critical performance indicators like instructor efficacy, student engagement, and course design, employing a Backpropagation Neural Network (BPNN) to analyse. For better accuracy, a hybrid Genetic Algorithm-Optimized Neural Network (GA-NN) is proposed, which enhances the convergence and reliability of prediction. The dataset includes structured questionnaires, expert scores, and student opinions across several colleges, which are Student Feedback & Course Evaluations, Expert & Peer Observation Scores, Wearable Sensor & Biometric Data, Institutional Academic Records, Video-Based Teaching Assessments, provides thorough analysis. Experimental results exhibit 98.3% classification accuracy, precision, recall, and F1score higher than 90 %, outperforming conventional methods. The originality comes from the adaptive optimization of neural networks for dynamic PE teaching settings, offering an intelligent, data-driven assessment framework. This system provides colleges with a sound tool for continuous physical education program improvement. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Huang, Y.; Li, S.
Author full names: Huang, Yuhua (60139389200); Li, Shengling (60139389300)
Title: Enhancing taekwondo training with modern technologies: the role of AI, ICT, and wearable devices in learning outcomes
Affiliations: College of Education, Jiangxi Institute of Applied Science and Technology, Nanchang, Jiangxi, China; Department of Physical Education, Luzhou Medical College, Luzhou, Sichuan, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Yuhua, College of Education, Jiangxi Institute of Applied Science and Technology, Nanchang, Jiangxi, China; Li, Shengling, Department of Physical Education, Luzhou Medical College, Luzhou, Sichuan, China
Abstract: Physical education and martial arts training have witnessed significant development through modern technologies like Artificial Intelligence (AI), Information and Communications Technology (ICT), and wearable devices. These innovations open new horizons for improving the quality of training in taekwondo. The study explores how modern technologies, AI, ICT, and wearable technology affect the learning, motivation, and skill development outcomes of students and teachers in taekwondo education. This mixed-method study conducts an online questionnaire-based survey and a semi-structured interview, including 248 participants for quantitative statistical review, and 227 participants proceeded for the qualitative interview process. Data were analyzed using the Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) and NVivo software. Compared to traditional training methods, AI-based training programs help trainees acquire skills in the long term. Moreover, these methods also make a significant difference in improving accuracy and speed. Technology tools, such as Virtual Reality (VR) and interactive applications, played an effective role in raising students’ engagement and motivation levels during theoretical and practical exercises. The study’s uniqueness is its exploration towards integrating AI information and communication technology and wearable devices into a unified educational framework within taekwondo. Technological instruments improve communication between teachers and learners. © 2025 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.

Authors: Yang, S.
Title: Sports and education integration tennis player selection and personalized training path planning based on artificial intelligence technology
Affiliations: Department of Physical Education, Shaanxi University of Technology, Hanzhong, Shaanxi, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Shiyu, Department of Physical Education, Shaanxi University of Technology, Hanzhong, Shaanxi, China
Abstract: The integration of sports and education through artificial intelligence (AI) is redefining traditional methods of athlete selection and personalized training, particularly in skill-demanding sports like tennis. Despite advancements in training science, conventional approaches still rely heavily on subjective assessments and uniform regimens, failing to accommodate individual differences in learning styles, biomechanics, cognitive load, and psychological resilience. This study addresses this gap by investigating the role of AI technologies - specifically machine learning algorithms, neural networks, augmented reality (AR), and motion capture systems - in optimizing tennis player recruitment and training personalization. A controlled experimental design was employed, involving 30 amateur and intermediate tennis players divided into AI-assisted and traditional training groups. AI tools such as motion capture systems, wearable sensors, and predictive neural network models were used to assess performance metrics, injury risk, and psychological readiness. The study found that players in the AI-supported group demonstrated significantly greater improvements in stroke accuracy (↑14.8%), serve speed (↑13.4 km/h), and reaction time (↓29 ms), along with a 60% reduction in injury occurrence and higher satisfaction scores across multiple training dimensions. Our contributions include: (1) a hybrid framework for integrating AI technologies into tennis training and talent identification; (2) empirical validation of AI's effectiveness in enhancing performance and injury prevention; and (3) thematic insights on adaptability and psychological impact from athletes using AI tools. These findings underscore AI's transformative potential to shift tennis coaching from intuition-based to data-driven, personalized methodologies, aligning with modern educational and athletic development goals. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Ahmed, I.; Brahmacharimayum, A.; Ali, R.H.; Khan, T.A.; Ahmad, M.O.
Author full names: Ahmed, Iftikhar (57210537072); Brahmacharimayum, Anushree (60097592300); Ali, Raja Hashim (56342801000); Khan, Talha Ali (55611739700); Ahmad, Muhammad Ovais (55748113700)
Title: Explainable AI for Depression Detection and Severity Classification From Activity Data: Development and Evaluation Study of an Interpretable Framework
Affiliations: Department of Software Engineering, University of Europe for Applied Sciences, Potsdam, Germany; Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Karlstads Universitet, Karlstad, Värmland, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Ahmed, Iftikhar, Department of Software Engineering, University of Europe for Applied Sciences, Potsdam, Germany; Brahmacharimayum, Anushree, Department of Software Engineering, University of Europe for Applied Sciences, Potsdam, Germany; Ali, Raja Hashim, Department of Software Engineering, University of Europe for Applied Sciences, Potsdam, Germany; Khan, Talha Ali, Department of Software Engineering, University of Europe for Applied Sciences, Potsdam, Germany; Ahmad, Muhammad Ovais, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Karlstads Universitet, Karlstad, Värmland, Sweden
Abstract: Background: Depression is one of the most prevalent mental health disorders globally, affecting approximately 280 million people and frequently going undiagnosed or misdiagnosed. The growing ubiquity of wearable devices enables continuous monitoring of activity levels, providing a new avenue for data-driven detection and severity assessment of depression. However, existing machine learning models often exhibit lower performance when distinguishing overlapping subtypes of depression and frequently lack explainability, an essential component for clinical acceptance. Objective: This study aimed to develop and evaluate an interpretable machine learning framework for detecting depression and classifying its severity using wearable-actigraphy data, while addressing common challenges such as imbalanced datasets and limited model transparency. Methods: We used the Depresjon dataset and applied Adaptive Synthetic Sampling (ADASYN) to mitigate class imbalance. We extracted multiple statistical features (eg, power spectral density mean and autocorrelation) and demographic attributes (eg, age) from the raw activity data. Five machine learning algorithms (logistic regression, support vector machines, random forest, XGBoost, and neural networks) were assessed via accuracy, precision, recall, F<inf>1</inf>-score, specificity, and Matthew correlation constant. We further used Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) and Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) to elucidate prediction drivers. Results: XGBoost achieved the highest overall accuracy of 84.94% for binary classification and 85.91% for multiclass severity. SHAP and LIME revealed power spectral density mean, age, and autocorrelation as top predictors, highlighting circadian disruptions’ role in depression. Conclusions: Our interpretable framework reliably identifies depressed versus nondepressed individuals and differentiates mild from moderate depression. The inclusion of SHAP and LIME provides transparent, clinically meaningful insights, emphasizing the potential of explainable artificial intelligence to enhance early detection and intervention strategies in mental health care. © Iftikhar Ahmed, Anushree Brahmacharimayum, Raja Hashim Ali, Talha Ali Khan, Muhammad Ovais Ahmad.

Authors: Argueta, L.R.; Aguiar, R.C.; Oliveira, S.; Sousa, M.; Carvalho, D.; Correia, M.V.
Author full names: Argueta, Luis Ruano (60050274900); Aguiar, Rafael Castro (57221246255); Oliveira, Sandro (60050412200); Sousa, Manoela Vieira (57200537261); Carvalho, Diogo V. (57225768292); Correia, Miguel V. (26321363500)
Title: Smart Vest for Physical Education (SV4PE): Physical Assessment Metrics via IMU and ECG
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Medical Measurements and Applications, MeMeA
Affiliations: Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Institute for Systems and Computer Engineering, Technology and Science, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Argueta, Luis Ruano, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Aguiar, Rafael Castro, Institute for Systems and Computer Engineering, Technology and Science, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Oliveira, Sandro, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Sousa, Manoela Vieira, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Carvalho, Diogo V., Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal; Correia, Miguel V., Universidade do Porto, Porto, Porto, Portugal
Abstract: There is currently a lack of objective, quantifiable metrics to evaluate children's health and athletic performance during Physical Education classes. To address this gap, the TexP@ct Consortium is developing a Smart Vest for Physical Education (SV4PE)-a textile engineered wearable solution that integrates a single triaxial Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) and electrocardiogram (ECG) sensors, embedded at the T8 spinal level. Designed for comfortable and unobtrusive use, the SV4PE enables recording and analysis of biomechanical and physiological data during physical activity. This paper presents the preliminary system validation and algorithm development for the SV4PE system, detailing the sensor fusion and signal processing methods used to extract metrics from live and recorded data, along with results from experimental and prototype datasets. The algorithms designed measure an athlete's heart rate, movement intensity, and effort, with additional post-exercise metrics to characterize fundamental movements such as walking, running, and jumping. Sensor fusion packages were implemented, combining acceleration and angular velocity, to correct sensor drifts and remove gravity components. Following filtering and resampling, walking and running metrics, such as cadence, distance and velocity, are extracted through gait event identification, using wavelet transforms. Jumping characteristics are derived from vertical acceleration using projectile motion equations to estimate jump height, take-off force, and power output. Lastly, heart rate is calculated from QRS peak detection in the ECG signal, and associated with subject metadata to evaluate exercise intensity and effort levels. Additional algorithms are under-development to assess fitness tests (e.g., mile run, shuttle run, push-ups, etc.), for team sport motion classification using machine learning, and for player localization within a playfield for detailed performance analysis. Ultimately, this work seeks to provide teachers and trainers with practical tools to objectively monitor and assess children's performance during sports and physical activities. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Zhang, Y.; Fu, X.; Wu, Z.
Title: A Case Study of Big Data and Artificial Intelligence in Physical Education
Source title: Journal of Cases on Information Technology
Affiliations: Guangdong Polytechnic Normal University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Ye, Guangdong Polytechnic Normal University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China; Fu, Xiang, Guangdong Polytechnic Normal University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China; Wu, Zexin, Guangdong Polytechnic Normal University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China
Abstract: This case study explores in depth the sports platform driven by big data and artificial intelligence (AI) in a certain university, aiming to solve the problems of uneven distribution of resources, lack of personalized teaching, and outdated evaluation system in traditional sports teaching. To meet these challenges, the authors have deployed a strong information technology (IT) infrastructure that integrates wearable devices, edge computing-based attitude estimation algorithms, and cloud analysis. This platform not only achieves automatic tracking and real-time feedback of student sports data but also provides personalized training suggestions, significantly improving the teaching effectiveness of physical education courses. Thanks to the edge computing architecture, the cost of cloud services has been reduced by 40%. Meanwhile, the modular design of the system enables it to be replicated and applied in school environments with weak internet of things (IoT) infrastructure, providing a technological pathway for other educational institutions to learn. © 2025 IGI Global. All rights reserved.

Authors: Akyel, Y.
Author full names: Akyel, Yakup (57205596195)
Title: Personal and professional drivers of wearable technology use: a model-based analysis among physical education teachers
Affiliations: Division of Classroom Education, Kırşehir Ahi Evran Üniversitesi, Kirsehir, Kirsehir, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Akyel, Yakup, Division of Classroom Education, Kırşehir Ahi Evran Üniversitesi, Kirsehir, Kirsehir, Turkey
Abstract: This study examines the factors influencing wearable technology adoption among physical education teachers by integrating the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB), Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), and Self-Determination Theory (SDT). The research investigates how intrinsic motivational factors (perceived competence, autonomy, and relatedness from SDT) and behavioral intentions (from TPB and TAM) together affect educators’ decisions to adopt wearable technologies. Using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM), data from 338 physical education teachers were analyzed to evaluate the proposed theoretical model. Results indicate that internal motivational dynamics significantly shape teachers’ openness to and intentions toward integrating wearable devices, alongside perceptions of the technology’s ease of use and usefulness. The findings underscore the importance of aligning technological tools with educators’ professional motivations and educational objectives to promote successful technology integration. This research advances the theoretical understanding of technology adoption in education and offers practical insights for designing professional development and policy initiatives. Targeted strategies should address both motivational and behavioral dimensions to support holistic and sustainable technology adoption in educational contexts. © 2025 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
Author Keywords: educational technology integration; motivational dynamics; structural equation modeling; teacher behavioral intentions; Wearable technology adoption

Title: Stakeholder Perspectives on Trustworthy AI for Parkinson Disease Management Using a Cocreation Approach: Qualitative Exploratory Study

Zamba-Papanicolaou, Eleni, ; Michailidou, Kyriaki, ; Christodoulou, Christiana, ; Chairta, Paraskevi P., ; Christodoulou, Kyproula, ; Almarcha-Menargues, Maria Luisa, ; Kurtis, Mónica M.,
Abstract: Background: Parkinson disease (PD) is the fastest-growing neurodegenerative disorder in the world, with prevalence expected to exceed 12 million by 2040, which poses significant health care and societal challenges. Artificial intelligence (AI) systems and wearable sensors hold potential for PD diagnosis, personalized symptom monitoring, and progression prediction. Nonetheless, ethical AI adoption requires several core principles, including user trust, transparency, fairness, and human oversight. Objective: This study aims to explore and synthesize the perspectives of diverse stakeholders, such as individuals living with PD, health care professionals, AI experts, and bioethicists. The aim was to guide the development of AI-driven digital health solutions, emphasizing transparency, data security, fairness, and bias mitigation while ensuring robust human oversight. These efforts are part of the broader Artificial Intelligence-Based Parkinson’s Disease Risk Assessment and Prognosis (AI-PROGNOSIS) European project, dedicated to advancing ethical and effective AI applications in PD diagnosis and management. Methods: An exploratory qualitative approach, based on 2 datasets constructed from cocreation workshops, engaged key stakeholders with diverse expertise to gather insights, ensuring a broad range of perspectives and enriching the thematic analysis. A total of 24 participants participated in the cocreation workshops, including 11 (46%) people with PD, 6 (25%) health care professionals, 3 (13%) AI technical experts, 1 (4%) bioethics expert, and 3 (13%) facilitators. Using a semistructured guide, key aspects of the discussion centered on trust, fairness, explainability, autonomy, and the psychological impact of AI in PD care. Results: Thematic analysis of the cocreation workshop transcripts identified 5 key main themes, each explored through various corresponding subthemes. AI trust and security (theme 1) was highlighted, focusing on data safety and the accuracy and reliability of the AI systems. AI transparency and education (theme 2) emphasized the need for educational initiatives and the importance of transparency and explainability of AI technologies. AI bias (theme 3) was identified as a critical theme, addressing issues of bias and fairness and ensuring equitable access to AI-driven health care solutions. Human oversight (theme 4) stressed the significance of AI-human collaboration and the essential role of human review in AI processes. Finally, AI’s psychological impact (theme 5) examined the emotional impact of AI on patients and how AI is perceived in the context of PD care. Conclusions: Our findings underline the importance of implementing robust security measures, developing transparent and explainable AI models, reinforcing bias mitigation and reduction strategies and equitable access to treatment, integrating human oversight, and considering the psychological impact of AI-assisted health care. These insights provide actionable guidance for developing trustworthy and effective AI-driven digital PD diagnosis and management solutions. ©Beatriz Alves, Ghada Alhussein, Sara Riggare, Therese Scott Duncan, Ali Saad, David M Lyreskog, Christos Chatzichristos, Ioannis Gerasimou, Stelios Hadjidimitriou, Leontios J Hadjileontiadis, Sofia B Dias, AI-PROGNOSIS Consortium.

Title: Wearable Tech and IoT for the Future of Fitness and Physical Education training system
Affiliations: Jizzakh State Pedagogical University, Jizzakh, Jizzakh Region, Uzbekistan; Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq; Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq; Department of Computer Science, University of Kirkuk, Kirkuk, Iraq; Faculty of Humanities & Pedagogy, Turan International University, Namangan, Namangan, Uzbekistan; Department of CS & IT, Kalinga University, Naya Raipur, CG, India
Authors with affiliations: Normatova, Aziza, Jizzakh State Pedagogical University, Jizzakh, Jizzakh Region, Uzbekistan; Hamedshnain, Ammar, Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq, Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq; Hameed, Marwah, Department of Computer Science, University of Kirkuk, Kirkuk, Iraq; Ahmatkhonovich, Azizov Marufkhuja, Faculty of Humanities & Pedagogy, Turan International University, Namangan, Namangan, Uzbekistan; Prashant, Patil Manisha, Department of CS & IT, Kalinga University, Naya Raipur, CG, India
Abstract: Wearable technology and the Internet of Things (IoT) are revolutionizing fitness and physical education by enabling real-time health monitoring and performance tracking. These advancements offer a data-driven approach to personalized training, enhancing both individual and group fitness programs. However, existing methods rely on generalized training plans that fail to address individual needs, leading to inefficiencies in performance improvement and injury prevention. Additionally, traditional fitness monitoring lacks real-time feedback, limiting users' ability to adjust workouts dynamically. To address these limitations, we propose a Cloud-based AI Analytics for Personalized Training Plans (C-AI-PTP) framework. This system integrates wearable sensors, IoT devices, and cloud computing to analyze physiological and biomechanical data in real time. AI-driven analytics generate personalized training recommendations based on users' fitness levels, goals, and real-time performance metrics. The proposed method allows continuous monitoring, adaptive feedback, and data-driven adjustments, enhancing training efficiency and reducing the risk of injuries. Coaches and educators can also use aggregated insights to design optimized physical education programs. Our findings demonstrate that C-AI-PTP significantly improves workout effectiveness, motivation, and injury prevention. Personalized insights enhance user engagement, while AI-powered analytics refine training plans over time. This approach marks a transformative shift in fitness and physical education, fostering a more intelligent, adaptive, and effective training system. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Hussein, L.; Yusupova, G.; Dilshodbek, M.; Kirit, D.D.

Title: Gamification and Artificial Intelligence in Physical Education using a wearable device For Athletes
Affiliations: Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq; Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq; Jizzakh State Pedagogical University, Jizzakh, Jizzakh Region, Uzbekistan; Faculty of Business Adminstration, Turan International University, Namangan, Namangan, Uzbekistan; Department of CS & IT, Kalinga University, Naya Raipur, CG, India
Authors with affiliations: Hussein, Laith, Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq, Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Najaf, Najaf, Iraq; Yusupova, Gulnoza, Jizzakh State Pedagogical University, Jizzakh, Jizzakh Region, Uzbekistan; Dilshodbek, Mamajonov, Faculty of Business Adminstration, Turan International University, Namangan, Namangan, Uzbekistan; Kirit, Dhablia Dharmesh, Department of CS & IT, Kalinga University, Naya Raipur, CG, India
Abstract: Gamification and Artificial Intelligence (AI) are revolutionizing physical education by enhancing athlete engagement, motivation, and performance tracking through wearable devices. These technologies provide an interactive and data-driven approach to training, optimizing fitness outcomes. Traditional physical education methods often lack real-time feedback, personalized training, and continuous motivation, leading to reduced effectiveness in athlete development. Additionally, conventional assessment techniques do not leverage AI-driven insights, limiting performance optimization. To address these challenges, we propose the Achieving Fitness Milestones Tracked by Wearable Device (AFMT-WD) framework, integrating AI and gamification elements. This framework enhances athlete engagement through adaptive training modules, real-time biometric monitoring, and personalized feedback mechanisms. AI-driven analytics interpret wearable data to tailor fitness programs, ensuring optimal progress tracking. The proposed method employs machine learning algorithms to analyze performance trends, suggest improvements, and dynamically adjust training plans based on individual athlete capabilities. Gamification elements such as rewards, challenges, and social leaderboards foster motivation and adherence to training regimens. Experimental results demonstrate that the AFMT-WD framework significantly improves athlete performance, engagement, and consistency in physical education programs. The integration of AI-powered wearables with gamification not only personalizes training but also enhances overall fitness outcomes, making physical education more interactive and effective © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Tan, S.
Title: Application of Art-Based Knowledge Management in Preschool Education: Promoting Children's Cognitive Development and Knowledge Creation
Affiliations: Hunan Vocational College of Electronic and Technology, Changsha, Hunan, China
Authors with affiliations: Tan, Silin, Hunan Vocational College of Electronic and Technology, Changsha, Hunan, China
Abstract: This article explores the integration of art-based knowledge management in preschool education using cloud computing and immersive technologies, like augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality. The proposed system combines optical character recognition, 3D modeling, physically based rendering, and artificial intelligence to create interactive AR picture books and virtual galleries, supporting cross-disciplinary learning. Smart wearable devices are integrated to provide personalized feedback and real-time progress management, enhancing the learning experience. Experimental results show that this approach significantly promotes children's cognitive development and knowledge creation, with small classes achieving 75% progress and large classes reaching 100%. Interaction frequencies varied from 0.14 to 0.20 times per minute, and technology evaluations indicated high effectiveness in learning outcomes and resource management. The findings suggest that combining cloud computing with AR/virtual reality technologies creates an immersive, interdisciplinary environment conducive to innovative preschool education. © 2025 IGI Global. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Art-Based Knowledge Management; Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality; Cloud Computing; Interdisciplinary Interactive Learning; Preschool Education

Title: IdentiARAT: Toward Automated Identification of Individual ARAT Items from Wearable Sensors
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Rehabilitation Robotics
Affiliations: Information and Technology, Technische Universität München, Munich, Bayern, Germany; Department of Sports Equipment and Materials, Technische Universität München, Munich, Bayern, Germany; Research Group Augmented Reality, Technische Universität München, Munich, Bayern, Germany; Lake Lucerne Institute, Vitznau, Switzerland

Abstract: This study explores the potential of using wrist-worn inertial sensors to automate the labeling of ARAT (Action Research Arm Test) items. While the ARAT is commonly used to assess upper limb motor function, its limitations include subjectivity and time consumption of clinical staff. By using IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) sensors and MiniROCKET as a time series classification technique, this investigation aims to classify ARAT items based on sensor recordings. We test common preprocessing strategies to efficiently leverage included information in the data. Afterward, we use the best preprocessing to improve the classification. The dataset includes recordings of 45 participants performing various ARAT items. Results show that MiniROCKET offers a fast and reliable approach for classifying ARAT domains, although challenges remain in distinguishing between individual resembling items. Future work may involve improving classification through more advanced machine-learning models and data enhancements. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Sumiya, M.; Nishimura, T.; Aizaki, K.; Hirata, I.; Tsukui, N.; Osuka, Y.; Wakuta, M.; Senju, A.

Title: Addressing the Ethical, Legal, and Social Issues of Healthtech in Education: Insights From Japan
Affiliations: Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan; The University of Osaka, Suita, Osaka, Japan; Department of Clinical Psychology, Hanazono University, Kyoto, Kyoto, Japan; Institute of Child Developmental Science Research, Shizuoka, Japan; Faculty of Global Studies, Reitaku University, Kashiwa, Chiba, Japan; Faculty of Education and Integrated Arts and Sciences, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sumiya, Motofumi, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, The University of Osaka, Suita, Osaka, Japan, Department of Clinical Psychology, Hanazono University, Kyoto, Kyoto, Japan; Nishimura, Tomoko, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, The University of Osaka, Suita, Osaka, Japan, Institute of Child Developmental Science Research, Shizuoka, Japan; Aizaki, Kyoko, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, Faculty of Global Studies, Reitaku University, Kashiwa, Chiba, Japan; Hirata, Ikue, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, The University of Osaka, Suita, Osaka, Japan, Faculty of Education and Integrated Arts and Sciences, Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan; Tsukui, Nobuaki, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, The University of Osaka, Suita, Osaka, Japan, Institute of Child Developmental Science Research, Shizuoka, Japan; Osuka, Yuko, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, Institute of Child Developmental Science Research, Shizuoka, Japan; Wakuta, Manabu, Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, Institute of Child Developmental Science Research, Shizuoka, Japan; Senju, A., Research Center for Child Mental Development, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka, Japan, The University of Osaka, Suita, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: The increasing application of health technology (healthtech) in educational settings, particularly for monitoring students’ mental health, has garnered significant attention. These technologies, which range from wearable devices to digital mental health screenings, offer new opportunities for enhancing student well-being and strengthening support systems. Numerous studies have explored the ethical, legal, and social issues (ELSIs) of healthtech in the field of psychiatry, highlighting its potential benefits while also acknowledging the inherent complexities and risks that demand careful consideration. However, the ELSIs related to the use of healthtech in educational settings remain largely overlooked and insufficiently addressed. This study provides an overview of items that should be considered by researchers, teachers, and education boards or committees to promote healthtech in the educational context. By adapting existing ELSI frameworks from educational technology and digital health, this study systematically reviews ethical concerns surrounding healthtech in schools. Expert consultations were conducted through a project consisting of members with expertise related to healthtech, including developers, a teacher, a school counselor, and university researchers, leading to the identification of 52 ELSI concerns categorized into 8 domains: consent, rights and privacy, algorithms, information management, evaluation, use, role of public institutions, and relationships with private companies. Using Japan as a case study, we examine regulatory and cultural factors affecting healthtech adoption in schools. The findings reveal critical challenges, such as ensuring informed consent for minors, protecting student privacy, preventing biased algorithmic decision-making, and maintaining transparency in data management. In addition, institutional factors, including the role of public education policies and private-sector involvement, shape the ethical landscape of healthtech implementation. This study highlights the need for multistakeholder collaboration to establish guidelines that balance innovation with ethical responsibility. The study underscores the need for a multifaceted approach to mitigate risks such as data misuse, inequitable access, and algorithmic bias, ensuring the ethical and effective use of healthtech in education. The fundamental ELSI framework for healthtech, including privacy, consent, and algorithms, can be applied to educational systems worldwide, while aspects related to public education policies should be considered in accordance with the specific context of each country and culture. Incorporating healthtech into the educational system helps address the barriers associated with traditional approaches, including limited resources, cost constraints, and logistical challenges. Researchers from universities and healthtech companies, along with educators and other stakeholders, should ensure that healthtech projects consider diverse ELSI concerns at every stage before and during implementation. ©Motofumi Sumiya, Tomoko Nishimura, Kyoko Aizaki, Ikue Hirata, Nobuaki Tsukui, Yuko Osuka, Manabu Wakuta, Atsushi Senju.
Author Keywords: education; ethical, legal, and social issues; health technology; school; well-being

Authors: Clark, H.; Venishetty, N.; Howell, S.; Deebel, N.A.; Muthigi, A.
Author full names: Clark, Haley (59741852000); Venishetty, Nikit (57988570300); Howell, Skyler (57210415701); Deebel, Nicholas Allen (57195233931); Muthigi, Akhil (56534335100)
Title: Utilization of artificial intelligence in Men’s Health: Opportunities for innovation and quality improvement
Affiliations: School of Medicine, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States; Paul L. Foster School of Medicine, El Paso, TX, United States; Division of Urology, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Department of Urology, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston Salem, NC, United States; Department of Urology, Houston Methodist Hospital, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, Haley, School of Medicine, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States; Venishetty, Nikit, Paul L. Foster School of Medicine, El Paso, TX, United States; Howell, Skyler, Division of Urology, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Deebel, Nicholas Allen, Department of Urology, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston Salem, NC, United States; Muthigi, Akhil, Department of Urology, Houston Methodist Hospital, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is reshaping the landscape of men’s health by enhancing diagnostic accuracy, personalizing treatment strategies, and improving clinical efficiency. This narrative review explores the applications and ethical considerations of AI technologies, including machine learning, deep learning, and natural language processing, in key areas of men’s health such as fertility, erectile dysfunction, Peyronie’s disease, testosterone deficiency, and premature ejaculation. In reproductive medicine AI improves sperm morphology assessment, embryo selection, and prediction of seminal quality, offering more objective and accurate alternatives to traditional methods. For erectile dysfunction, AI supports diagnosis through advanced imaging, wearable sensors, and predictive modeling, while also contributing to drug discovery. In the context of Peyronie’s disease, AI enhances curvature assessment and three-dimensional modeling, improving diagnostic precision and surgical planning. AI also holds promise in improving the evaluation of testosterone deficiency by optimizing symptom questionnaires. Furthermore, AI-powered chatbots are emerging as accessible tools for patient education across various men’s health topics, including pre-consultation support for conditions such as premature ejaculation and vasectomy counseling. Despite AI’s advancements in men’s health, challenges remain in ensuring ethical implementation, protecting data privacy, patient autonomy, and promoting algorithm transparency. This review highlights the transformative potential of AI in the future of men’s health while emphasizing the importance of responsible integration guided by clinical validation, regulatory oversight, and adherence to ethical principles. © The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer Nature Limited 2025.

Authors: Zhang, L.; Park, J.Y.; Menon, N.; Ranade, N.; Yu, B.; Tan, S.
Title: Are You With Us? A Real-Time Engagement Analytics with Machine Learning in Online Learning Environments
Source title: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Affiliations: Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Noord-Brabant, Netherlands; George Mason University, Fairfax, VA, United States; Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Trinity University, San Antonio, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Linghan, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Noord-Brabant, Netherlands; Park, Jung-yeon, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA, United States; Menon, Nirup M., George Mason University, Fairfax, VA, United States; Ranade, Nupoor, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Yu, Bo, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA, United States; Tan, Sheng, Trinity University, San Antonio, TX, United States
Abstract: Online learning environments cannot often evaluate students’ attentiveness and engagement in minute detail. Our project addresses this gap by developing a real-time predictive engine to better understand students’ learning states, enabling more active learning and adaptive teaching in online settings. This engine leverages a combination of digital tools to predict cognitive load and engagement in real-time. In this work, we outline the procedures and some preliminary findings from developing and testing this predictive model using data from wearables and webcams. These devices captured physiological signals, facial expressions, eye gazes, and head poses to measure engagement levels in content-heavy classrooms. To build the model, we manually selected and extracted features from a pre-existing database containing sensory data. The model categorized students into two engagement levels: low and high. Following model development, we conducted an experimental study involving two 30-minute machine learning (ML) lectures with 12 college students. Alongside physiological data, self-reported survey data on engagement were collected as the ground truth. The engagement levels predicted by the engine were found to be highly associated with their self-reports on engagement (approximately 50% of variance shared). Results demonstrated that electrodermal activity (EDA), recorded via E4 wearable devices, was higher during challenging lecture segments than in easier ones. Additionally, variability in EDA levels during lectures correlated with self-reported stress, suggesting a potential link between stress and engagement. Through this work, we present insights into developing multimodal learning analytics based on real-time psychophysiological signals and learning behavioral data. These insights highlight the potential for integrating wearable and webcam data to enhance online learning. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Kumar, C.R.; Pulavendran, M.; Nageswaran, S.
Author full names: Kumar, Challa Revanth (59953743800); Pulavendran, Manikandan (59207983400); Nageswaran, Sharmila (59282660800)
Title: CONTINUOUS POSTURE TRACKING AND FEEDBACK SYSTEM TO PREVENT NECK STRAIN AND EYE RELATED ISSUES
Affiliations: Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, TN, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Challa Revanth, Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, TN, India; Pulavendran, Manikandan, Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, TN, India; Nageswaran, Sharmila, Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, TN, India
Abstract: The prevalence of physical health conditions brought on by poor sitting postures is rising, particularly among sedentary employees and students. Working with computers at the wrong viewing angle and distance can cause neck strain and eye-related deficiency syndrome. The proposed system will solve this problem by designing and developing a sensor-based posture recognition system (SPRS). The system has base components like the ESP32, HC-SR04—an ultrasonic sensor—and MPU6050—an inertial measurement unit sensor (IMU). The system will continuously monitor the viewing screen distance from the computer to the person working with the computer and the viewing angle of that person concerning the screen. The optimal value for maintaining viewing distance is 50 to 70 cm, and the viewing angle is 15 to 30 degrees. The outcome of the proposed work confirms that the system constantly tracks the angle and distance obtained from the sensors and provides alarming feedback to the users whenever the tracked values are not at the optimal level. In the future, the system will be developed without using any wearable sensor, which will give more convenience to the user. The proposed system will include machine learning concepts to classify the different sitting posture styles. © 2025 by ASME.

Authors: Chouhan, G.; Sharma, U.; Mathur, A.; Khan, A.; Suman, S.
Author full names: Chouhan, Gangotri (59915764000); Sharma, Urvesh (59915047700); Mathur, Arun (59914518400); Khan, Aamir (59915764100); Suman, Shiv (59915764200)
Title: Predictive Analytics for Injury Prevention in Physical Education Using Machine Learning Models
Affiliations: Department of Sports & Physical Education, Suresh Gyan Vihar University, Jaipur, RJ, India; Department of Physical Education & Sports, Banasthali Vidyapith, Vanasthali, RJ, India
Authors with affiliations: Chouhan, Gangotri, Department of Sports & Physical Education, Suresh Gyan Vihar University, Jaipur, RJ, India; Sharma, Urvesh, Department of Physical Education & Sports, Banasthali Vidyapith, Vanasthali, RJ, India; Mathur, Arun, Department of Sports & Physical Education, Suresh Gyan Vihar University, Jaipur, RJ, India; Khan, Aamir, Department of Physical Education & Sports, Banasthali Vidyapith, Vanasthali, RJ, India; Suman, Shiv, Department of Physical Education & Sports, Banasthali Vidyapith, Vanasthali, RJ, India
Abstract: In recent years, there has been a growing concern over the increasing number of injuries among high school students participating in physical education programs, particularly during sports activities. These injuries, ranging from minor sprains to stress fractures, can significantly impact student health and disrupt the learning process. Focused on addressing this issue, applying predictive analytics along with machine learning models to figure out the possible at-risk group of students timely interventions are set in motion by this study regarding the possibility to predict and potentially prevent injuries based on machine learning algorithms. Comprehensive datasets containing a combination of all demographic information related to physical and other metrics; injury history information; and detailed activity data reported from wearable equipment will be provided. Models that were applied to achieve this end are Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machines (SVM), and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN). Results obtained from this indicate that the RNN model is the strongest one compared to others regarding accuracy since it identified the widest range of injury types with a very minor error. Random Forest also did quite well, whereas SVM and ANN showed lower accuracies, mostly while predicting complex injuries. Hence, the general results indicate that machine learning via real-time data analysis from wearables can significantly enhance injury prevention practices in PE. This approach provides educators and coaches with early warnings regarding the potential injury risks, allowing them to undertake preventive measures in improving both safety among students and athletic performance. © 2025 IEEE.

Title: A Flexible Vibrotactile Feedback System for Rapid Prototyping
Affiliations: Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Paniagua, Carlos, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan; Ota, Hiroki, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan; Hirao, Yutaro, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan; Perusquía-Hernández, Monica, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan; Uchiyama, Hideaki, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan; Kiyokawa, Kiyoshi, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Nara, Japan
Abstract: Tape-Tics is a flexible, modular vibrotactile feedback system integrating LEDs and vibration motors. Users can adjust vibration intensity, LED colors, and configurations via Bluetooth Low Enery (BLE), enabling operation based on predefined settings. Built with flexible printed circuit (FPC) technology, Tape-Tics adapts to curved surfaces, enhancing its versatility in education, research, and art. In a hands-on workshop, participants assembled and operated Tape-Tics to explore vibrotactile technology. Using the GUI controller, they configured vibration patterns and developed unique applications. Surveys showed participants' understanding of haptics improved significantly, and they rated Tape-Tics highly as an educational tool. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Goussain, B.G.C.D.S.; Moura, R.A.D.; Luche, J.R.D.; Andrade, H.D.S.; Silva, M.B.
Author full names: Goussain, Blaha Gregory Correia dos Santos (59371937200); Moura, Roque Antônio (57947621500); Luche, José Roberto Dale (57215471664); Andrade, Herlandi de Souza (57189242632); Silva, Messias Borges (25947743000)
Title: Enhancing Learning with Physiological Measures: A Systematic Review of Applications in Neuroeducation
Source title: International Conference on Computer Supported Education, CSEDU - Proceedings
Affiliations: School of Engineering Sciences, Universidade Estadual Paulista "Júlio de Mesquita Filho", Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Tickle College of Engineering, Knoxville, TN, United States; Universidade de São Paulo, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Goussain, Blaha Gregory Correia dos Santos, School of Engineering Sciences, Universidade Estadual Paulista "Júlio de Mesquita Filho", Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil, Tickle College of Engineering, Knoxville, TN, United States; Moura, Roque Antônio, School of Engineering Sciences, Universidade Estadual Paulista "Júlio de Mesquita Filho", Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Luche, José Roberto Dale, School of Engineering Sciences, Universidade Estadual Paulista "Júlio de Mesquita Filho", Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Andrade, Herlandi de Souza, Universidade de São Paulo, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Silva, Messias Borges, School of Engineering Sciences, Universidade Estadual Paulista "Júlio de Mesquita Filho", Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil, Universidade de São Paulo, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil
Abstract: This systematic review explores the integration of neuroscience and education, focusing on physiological monitoring technologies such as Electrodermal Activity (EDA), Heart Rate (HR), and Skin Temperature (ST). These metrics, facilitated by wearable devices and machine learning models, provide real-time insights into student engagement, emotional states, and academic performance. The analysis synthesizes findings from recent studies, highlighting the transformative potential of physiological measures in creating adaptive, student-centered learning environments. The review examines the use of physiological monitoring in education for stress assessment, motivation enhancement, and academic performance optimization, while also addressing challenges in reliability, ethics, and implementation. By identifying existing gaps, it proposes directions for future research to refine these tools and promote their widespread adoption in educational contexts. These advancements underscore the role of physiological insights in fostering emotional well-being and optimizing teaching practices, marking a significant step toward evidence-based, neuroeducation-informed strategies. © © 2025 by SCITEPRESS - Science and Technology Publications, Lda.

Authors: Kilaru, M.; Surya, S.; Boianapalli, M.; Vijaya Kumar, S.; Mamta Thakur, D.; Chakravarthi, M.
Author full names: Kilaru, Mrudula (58139422000); Surya, S. (56038387000); Boianapalli, Sindhu (60093106700); Vijaya Kumar, S. (59743339700); Mamta Thakur, Dr (59742502800); Chakravarthi, Maddikera Kalyan (55308250400)
Title: Adaptive Learning Systems: Integrating IoT Sensors with Machine Learning for Dynamic Curriculum Adjustment
Affiliations: Siddhartha Academy of Higher Education, Bagalkot, India; Sri Ramachandra Institute of Higher Education and Research, Chennai, TN, India; Department of CSE, CVR College of Engineering, Ibrahimpatnam, TS, India; B.S.Abdur Rahman University, Chennai, TN, India; Department of Mathematics, Chaitanya Bharathi Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, TS, India; Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, University of Technology and Applied Sciences Muscat, Muscat, Muscat, Oman
Authors with affiliations: Kilaru, Mrudula, Siddhartha Academy of Higher Education, Bagalkot, India; Surya, S., Sri Ramachandra Institute of Higher Education and Research, Chennai, TN, India; Boianapalli, Sindhu, Department of CSE, CVR College of Engineering, Ibrahimpatnam, TS, India; Vijaya Kumar, S., B.S.Abdur Rahman University, Chennai, TN, India; Mamta Thakur, Dr, Department of Mathematics, Chaitanya Bharathi Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, TS, India; Chakravarthi, Maddikera Kalyan, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, University of Technology and Applied Sciences Muscat, Muscat, Muscat, Oman
Abstract: The broad implementation of learning statistics in different curriculum contexts is still difficult, despite encouraging results in universities. Secondary and primary institutions are hesitant to employ these technologies. By providing individualized education encounters catered to each student's requirements, machine learning (ML) based adaptive learning platforms have revolutionized learning by increasing student involvement and results. Physical training can now be communicated through technology via the growth of the Internet of Things (IoT), which links affordable, diverse gadgets and sensors to open, public spaces. This research investigates the relationship between curriculum adjustment, a crucial aspect of sports, and physical activities using a decision tree. This platform gathers vital statistics from IoT-based wearable sensors, and by virtualization of the gadget, it interacts with the statistics in real time. Implementing and promoting physical education and learning curriculum in the real world and building healthier atmosphere platforms to address the health surveillance problems brought on by IoT sensors are the solutions suggested by the empirical evaluation. Research results demonstrate the remarkable physical activity surveillance accomplished by the suggested approach in comparison to the traditional technologies. With excellent accuracy ratios (98.5%), estimation ratios (96.6%), communication ratios (94.5%), functioning ratios (95.3%), effectiveness ratios (93.4), F-values (92.3%), and lower error rates (17.6%), the computational evaluation of physical education curriculum can assist learners and enhance the related facets of their physical skills. © 2025 IEEE.

Authors: Wang, Z.; Hu, X.; Fan, Z.; Fei, W.
Title: Wearable piezoelectrical muscle monitoring system for swimming analysis neural network
Affiliations: School of Marxism Studies, Yiwu Industrial and Commercial College, Yiwu, Zhejiang, China; School of Public Instruction, Wenzhou Polytechnic, Zhejiang, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Zhiqiang, School of Marxism Studies, Yiwu Industrial and Commercial College, Yiwu, Zhejiang, China; Hu, Xujie, School of Marxism Studies, Yiwu Industrial and Commercial College, Yiwu, Zhejiang, China; Fan, Zile, School of Marxism Studies, Yiwu Industrial and Commercial College, Yiwu, Zhejiang, China; Fei, Weining, School of Public Instruction, Wenzhou Polytechnic, Zhejiang, China
Abstract: Swimming is one of the most popular worldwide sports, which offers the players healthy body, improved fitness, and endless enjoyment due to its easy accessibility and year-round availability. Monitoring swimmers can aid in the development and participation of swimming sport. However, due to the difficulty of in-water monitoring, the existing methods in tool box are still limited. In this paper, a more accessible wearable monitoring system based on a flexible piezoelectric device is developed. This system collects muscle contracting and relaxing information by measuring its generated force on a Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) sensor. Then the information is transmitted via a low-frequency radio frequency (RF) signal to the receiver on land. This information is analyzed using a convolutional neural network and the classification of different strokes is realized. The system also supports monitoring at two positions by wearing multiple devices on the body. By integrating data from multiple positions, the analysis algorithm achieves a higher prediction accuracy of over 95%. This work demonstrates that the combination of wearable monitoring devices, the Internet of Things, and Artificial Intelligence, which holds significant promise for sports education, research, promotion, and development. © © 2025 The Institute of Electronics, Information and Communication Engineers.
